this is these questions are questions young people are asking. And the church doesn't get to say,
Hey, we blew it. So we in the past, so we have no, we don't get to be involved in this conversation
at all. That's not an option. Right. Right. We've got to learn how to do this. Well,
how do we have this conversation? Well, right. Um, and I think we just talked about it here,
which is you start with identity in Christ and that's where this starts. And you start with our
value to Christ. Um, it isn't that he's going to affirm everything about us. That's ridiculous,
but he is going to affirm our value to him. He is going to affirm that we're precious and treasure
to him every single time, a hundred percent. So far as I can tell, I've not seen anything.
Nothing changes our value to him. Even being lost doesn't change our value to him. It just
changes our, the nature of our relationship with him. And so I, I was struck by that. And I, you
know, you, maybe this is the counselor in me, but it makes me want to travel back in time somehow and
sit down with those young ladies and go, okay, everything you just heard is lies. Everything
you just heard up there. Not true. Yeah. Mom and dad, that conference you went to, everything you
heard. Nope. Nope. Start over. Start as great. That was bad. You probably sensed it was bad.
You felt like something was bad. Um, I remember distinctly the first time I read the first book
I ever read that presented sex and the Christian world is transactional. And I remembered thinking
like, I mean, I guess that's right. This book has sold millions of copies to Christians, but
I mean, no, it's not right for me, but I guess it must be right for other people. So
I must be the oddball until I used the book a couple of times and had people, you know,
respond in such a way, let me know, like, no, no, no, it's not, it's apparently not just me.
And then good research proved otherwise. I, I would love to see the church regain,
I guess, footing here. Cause it's needed. Right. Not guiding young people is not an option.
Right. Yeah. Did you have a question? Well, I, well, my, my next step was just
going to be kind of where you let us Chris. Cause it was, okay, we, if, if you're a listener
and you are somebody who's like, man, this has really been hard for me. I have a lot of wounds.
Um, I have, I have, you know, whether it's a deconstructed relationship with Jesus or with
the church or, and there's just kind of like a lot of question marks, where do you go from there?
And what it sounds like first is you need to start with your identity in Christ. Right. And then,
and then build from there, but, but your value understanding your value as a creation, as a
daughter or a son of God and what that means seems like a great first step. Um, I think from there,
what would be maybe your next admonishment? Okay. If you're going to start there, here's the track
you go on. Yeah. What? Cause how do you, how do you kind of rebuild from that? Where would you
other, other than, I mean, and maybe it is seek counsel. Maybe it is, I don't know. And I know
that Brandon, we were talking briefly before that we're kind of, we're kind of like, we were a little
bit trepidatious maybe about just throwing out names of goals into this person. Right. You know,
well, I think kind of give some nuance to that conversation maybe. Yeah. I think like we're
saying, even if we were to recommend a book or, you know, whatever, you still have to use the same,
the same method for that of like, go to scripture first, excuse me, um, go to scripture first. And,
um, and then yeah, surround yourself with wise people and sorry, I'm going to get some water.
Surround yourself with wise people, get counseling, get therapy. Um, but don't take even one resource
that we bring up or mention as gospel because that is part of the danger. And so, um, yeah,
what would you say, Chris? Well, and even as we talked about several times, even our understanding
of scripture needs to be intentional. It needs to be sophisticated. Like it's, it's not just,
I found a verse in the middle of proverbs and that's all I need to know about parenting.
I'm done, you know, spare the rods, boil the child. I'm done. I don't need to learn anything
else. We're finished. Like that's, that is a, that it's just a, such a misunderstanding of
what scripture is of what it teaches of how we're supposed to engage with it. And I, so I just, I
want, I want to encourage people. You, you look to scripture first and you make sure you're studying
it wisely and well. Um, so that's that I think is important, but I think so. Yes, that's one.
And then you go to the sources that are trustworthy sources, sources that have been proven to be
trustworthy. We're not the enemy of science. Look for those who actually have research. I'm amazed
not only in the Christian world, but in the non-Christian world, how often people just
publish their opinion about something. And all of a sudden it's gospel. Like, uh, no,
that's not how the Christians and non-Christians need to learn how to use good research and,
and how to unpack things and how to not just go like, Oh, no, that's, this feels right.
Or it kind of feels right. Or there's something to this. I just, I feel like there's so much more.
And so I, yes, all of those things are needed. We need to do the work, grow up and do the work,
um, and see that it's going to take some, it's going to take some energy. It's going to take
some time, but you probably spent many, many years and many hours preparing for your career.
It's probably worth spending a dozen or so hours preparing to be a parent or preparing to
understand sexuality within marriage, read a few decent books. Um, and I feel like those are,
those are some great, um, some great places to start. And, and, and, but for a lot of us,
there is going to be a trauma based to this. I think, uh, obviously I think there's a lot of
people who have been traumatized and I don't mean that, you know, that don't mean that using that
word too flippantly, but they have faced mental trauma, spiritual trauma, some cases really
from what they've been told. And so, and that's what they've been shown and what they tried to
live out. Really. And that's, that can be very expensive. The expensive meaning, oh, like a cost
on yourself. Yes. Yeah. Yeah. Also the therapy. Yes. And all the other things too. Yeah. But I
think that's a good point of like, yeah, take time to do the hard work or spend the money you need to
for therapy and good training. Because I think like we've mentioned multiple times, it does affect
most parts of our life, even in ways we don't understand. And so it's, yeah, sexuality is a
big part of our life and healthy sex within marriage is a big part of our life. But it's
so much more than that, that like we've talked about when it comes to relationships and our
understanding of who we are before the Lord and our relationship with him, um, and the body of
Christ. And so, yeah, I think like you're saying it's worth doing the hard work to rebuild. And,
and we've talked about this before. I don't, um, there are voices out in culture who are talking
about this a lot, but I think we have to be careful because some of them while doing good research and
making sure that the word gets out of the damage that's been done, they're not always offering
things that, um, are healing and our answers to the questions. And I think that's also a, um,
just a cautionary word of like, yeah, if they've done great research and they're getting the word
out about damage that's been done, yeah, that's really valuable in getting the word out of what
needs to not be done in the future, but we don't need to stop there. It's just like we've talked
about here. We don't stop with the deconstruction. We rebuild and have, how do we have healthy
conversations about this again? And maybe taking those people's ideas for, um, for healing.
And for how to move forward. Like we were talking about even the scheduling babies, like, yeah,
in, in a way of like, let's now test what, what the response is to those, those researchers who
are saying, okay, these are, this is the research I've done. This is the damage done. And now here's
how I, how I think we need to move forward. Right. It's okay. So do good, like, you know,
look at the good research and then, then take that, you know, the, the next steps. And I think
then also just test those as well. Yeah, test them. Yeah. Yes. And I think, so I think what you said
is a good point, Brian, as we have seen, especially in regards to some of these topics are very
reactive. I actually, since you guys have texted earlier, I feel like we could do almost a whole
season on Christians overreacting to things and how that inspires, uh, deconstruction. And I think
this is, this is an example of that. Like we're seeing Christians decon, I mean, we're seeing
Christians overreact now to this problem. Right. Right. And, and that's not, that's not,
it's not an improvement. Right. And it's not a godly response to, I think it's a natural response.
And I mentioned this in the last episode, but it is a natural response to be angry and to be bitter,
but it's not a biblical response to sit in anger and bitterness forever. Like that's not the,
that's not where God calls us to. And certainly not how we need to then interact with this
conversation going forward forever. Like that's just not, and it's not, it's understand, like it,
I mean, the emotion of it makes sense when there was so much trauma caused, but, but I think we
have to go back to how does God call us to walk as Christians in these conversations and walk like
Christ, even when we've been hurt and traumatized and how we go back to those biblical conversations.
You know, it goes back to the like all truth is God's truth conversation of like,
just because you have been mistaught a lot of this and feel like you have been
oppressed as a woman in this conversation, doesn't mean no men have any truth about this
conversation. You know, like stuff like that is very reactionary of like, well, therefore,
then you can never say anything about this as a man because, you know, men have misused this.
And it's like, no, that's, let's go back to the heart of Jesus and how we interact
and how we behave and, and do that even when we've been hurt in some way. I don't know.
So yeah, reactionary. That's like a whole different, we've been talking about that for a long time.
I mean, I started listing in my head all the different times that Christians react to something
foolishly. And I'm like, man, and it's probably what almost, if something was going to send me
over the edge of deconstruction, it would have been that. It would have been the times that I've
run into Christian responses to something. I'm like, you Christians.
Well, and it just pushes us, I think on one side, it causes people to deconstruct because of how
Christians are acting. On the other side, it pushes us to do the opposite of what we're saying
of like, we're just going to go to the opposite of this idea and now believe that. Yes. Because
that's not better either. Right. It just seems a little lazy. Yeah. It's a switch rather than a
dial and switches are always easier. Right. I got to do is click. I don't have to figure out.
Okay. What's good and what's bad. I don't have to test it and keep that, which is good. I can just,
you know, right. But it's, but when you've been traumatized, it's hard to keep any part of it.
And that's true. You could say speak to that as a therapist. And I know we need to wrap up soon,
but, um, yeah, I think it is hard. What I've seen walking with friends is when something has
contained a lot of lies, it is naturally really hard to keep any piece of it because it reminds
you of the really bad parts of it. Yeah. That was a really intense part of our conversation with
Catherine at one point was how hard it was to make any comeback. Cause it's like, well, I know I can
be totally fooled by this. I know there are people willing to lie to me about this. How do I know you
aren't right? Right. And well, fair. Like how do you answer that? Like, no, well, it's not possible
that anybody else would, but we're the first one you experienced. No, that's fair. Yeah. It's hard.
So prayerfully, what I would, we would say our encouragement to anybody would be don't
give up on this. Keep reconstructing, keep challenging those thoughts. Don't,
if something you got in the past was a lie, it's a lie. That doesn't mean everything is a lie.
And how do we, how do we deal with that? Well, these are some tools. These are some tools
for you to move forward with freedom, which is our hope more, the more connected to the truth.
So there you go. Great. Thank you guys.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you heard
or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us. If you have questions
or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org.
Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up.
Trust God. Search for answers.
